Description: "The government is using electronic surveillance to monitor individuals under self-quarantine after returning from countries ravaged by coronavirus."

Government to launch contact tracing application. "Through the application christened mSafari, Public Service Vehicles (PSV) operators and passengers will be required to provide critical data that will help trace back the movements of infected or suspected cases. Matatus, taxis and motorbike operators will be required to collect contact details of every passenger which will automatically register on the mSafari platform."
Five journalists granted parole after spreading disinformation relating to coronavirus
Kaka Touda Mamane Goni, detained. dissemination of data likely to disturb public order.
Fake news. Kenya arrests 23-year old aspiring blogger and influencer for peddling fake news. Unclear if he was actually pushing false narratives-- need to follow up w Africa.
A News24 journalist was shot at in Yeoville, Johannesburg

"Just in that fake news/ disinformation about #COVID19 becomes a criminal offence in South Africa." Under the Disaster Management Act, section 11(4)1/: "Any person who publishes any statement, through any medium, including social media, with the intention to deceive any other person about— (a) COVID-19; (b) COVID-19 infection status of any person; or (c) any measure taken by the Government to address COVID-19, commits an offence."
Journalist Robert Alai charged with spreading false informatmion relating to coronavirus pandemic
Blogger Cyprian Nyakundi arrested by police over post made about coronavirus on social media

After the March 25 government announcement of the release of 4,011 prisoners to prevent the spread of COVID19 in the prisons, Fekadu Mahtemework, who was imprisoned on a technicality in a tax case and was in our 2019 prison census, is freed. We confirmed with several sources that he was home as of March 26.
Members of church attack journalists who were monitoring restrictions on movement relating to coronavirus

TV reporter Tholi Totali Glody was run down by police in Likasi. Glody works for one of Likasi's leading TV stations, Alfajari TV, whose programme director told RSF that, after explaining to two policemen that he was covering respect for the lockdown, Glody was chased by the police and knocked off the motorcycle, breaking a leg and sustaining injuries to his face and an arm.
David Njagi Freelance
Link: Muthoki Conversation on March 24 with Winnie Kamau (+721754349) of the Kenya Freelancers Association.

Description: Yayesew Shimelis, a journalist with the state-owned Tigray TV who also contributes to a column to the Feteh Magazine and runs his own YouTube channel was arrested today on allegations of false news in connection to COVID19. According to tweets by @befeqe and private conversation between CPJ and two other sources, he was arrested in connection to a video posted yesterday in which he claimed that religious leaders in Ethiopia have been ordered to prepare 200,000 graves for expected COVID19 deaths. Earlier today, before Yayesew’s arrest, the ruling party in the Tigray bureau of the ruling prosperity party is said to have issued a press statement today calling for legal measures against those who spread false news and cause panic, and specifically cited Yayesew. They also called out another journalist by name, Tigray TV’s Medhin Gebreselassie, who is said to have claimed that 300,000 people would die in the Tigray region from the coronavirus. Yayesew apologise for the video, which has been taken down already, in a tweet today, according to @befeqe. I suggest for now we just retweet Befekadu. Our advocacy ask needs to be nuanced and I want to listen to the video before I come up with it.
Angela Nkwo Akpolu manhandled, phone seized for snapping quarantine centers
Regulation that criminalizes spreading falsehood on coronovirus subject to a 20 year jaril term or a hefty fine or both
Samuel Wazizi habeus corupus postponed. Defence and state lawyers fail to appear in court because of conflicting information about court closing over COVID-19
Link: Confirmed with ABA observer and lawyer

Description: Makes u-trun on previous day decision that court sessions cancelled, now no more than 50 -people in court. Concern about more dealys for awating trial journos and appeals, etc,
Economic effects of small publications like M&G. Editor appeals for financial help because of effects of the pandemic on adverstising revenue, etc, and that they can't pay staff or billls
Another employee based at SABC HQ found tested and confirmed coronvirus case
Information minister says Journalists need ID cards to move around in Lockdown
Press Union makes uregent request for financial assistance, says many media may have to suspend work, following economic meltdown and effects of COVID-19
Frank Payne flogged. Press Union of Liberia Condemned Payne's follogging, on oders of LDEA boss after the journalist tried to report none-compliance of social disnce regulations

During a press conference to provide updates on the Coronavirus, the Chief Administrative Secretary from the ministry of health refused to take questions from the media. There is speculation that they did not want to be asked about a 13 year old boy who was killed by a “stray” bullet from police who were enforcing a curfew on March 30.

Gregory Murithi, a cameraman with Weru TV, was assaulted by police officers on March 28, 2020 at Mitunguu market in Imenti South district, Meru County. Murithi was recording local officials forcefully evicting traders, assaulting market women, and scattering their wares while claiming to be enforcing social distancing measures at the market. One of the police officers tried to take away his camera, they ordered the journalist to delete footage, but he stood his ground. The journalist reported the matter at Mitunguu police station, but according to Nairobi news he was kept waiting for two hours before police recorded the incident in the OB (Occurrence Book).

John Kiarie (an MP). Not sure this would be mandate. A member of parliament, John Kiarie, was summoned yesterday by police and questioned about a Facebook post in which he claimed that there were 7,000 kenyans in quarantine, who had arrived back in the country between Wednesday and Sunday last week. The MP also said that the country has limited testing capacity, and that the government is communicating low estimates. He further estimated that by May Kenya will have at least 10,000 cases of COVID19. He then called on the government to communicate the real gravity of the situation, start establishing isolation centres around the country, mass produce masks and ventilators etc. He was released after he agreed to issue a clarification on his “alarming post” His clarification includes him saying the he based the figure of 10,000 on a scientific study. On March 30, the minister of health, who had earlier publicly condemned the MP for his comments, told a press conference that preliminary modelling indicated that Kenya would have about 5,000 to 10,000 cases of COVID19 by mid-April, absent drastic intervention.
Police dispersed several newspaper vendors and arrested four for violating the presidential directive for national lockdown.

Two journalists Khaya Koko & Sesona Ngqakamba were covering a police brutality case w.r.t the lockdown. Some of the officers' colleagues, who appeared to have been drinking, became very aggressive towards the two jouranlists.

This one is connected to the above incident of Pastor Yiga, PML Daily reports that the Uganda Communications Commission has written to three tv stations asking them to show cause why regulatory sanctions shouldn’t be taken against them, in connection to their coverage of COVID19. The stations, BBS TV, NTV and Spark TV could also face criminal charges of actions “likely to spread infection of any disease” for which those convicted could face up to 7 years in prison. According to PML Daily, the UCC accuses the stations of airing content with the potential “to confuse, divert and mislead” the public. The allegations against BBS and Spark tv arise from the stations having broadcasted Pastor Yiga’s comments that COVID19 is a hoax. NTV is accused of giving a platform to one Simon Senyonga on march 26, who is said to have made “objectionable” comments about COVID 19. I am trying to second-source this since it does not seem that NTV, BBS or Spark TV are reporting this.
Required to carry press cards to move around
E.O of GNN asked to provide source of story about COVID-19
Kaizolo was attacked by  LDEA officials while covering live, attempts by police to clear marketers in Liberia's COVID-19 response
NCDC, partners Premium Times, Africa check to check fake news on COVID-19
Officials of bthe Delta state tax force attacked journalists, Micheal Ikeogu and Mathew Omonigho while they monitored the level of complaionce to stay-at-home directives for their report
Journalist, Charles Yates Interrogated by NSA for social mefdia post alleging corruption from government in the implementation of health strategies to curb COVID-19

Not mandate but worrying. Two people (Husband and wife I think), Boniface Elias Mwita and Rosemary Elias Mwita, were arrested in Dar es Salaam and are now facing charges of spreading false news about Coronavirus. According to a post on Jamii Forums, while riding in a public transport minibus (dala dala) from Tabata to Muhibili Hospital in Dar es Salaam, the two were heard by fellow passengers claiming that Coronavirus is a hoax, and alleged that the reason schools were closed is because the govt does not have money to feed students in school, and that the government just wants foreign aid. The fellow passengers in the dala dala, after listening to the “fake news”, ordered the driver to drive to a police station, where the two Mwitas were arrested. Investigations into the case are over, and the file has been submitted to prosecutors.
Outlets denied access to Aso Rock. over 80 journalists

An NTV Cameraperson, Peter Wainaina, was today afternoon assaulted by police in Mombasa Kenya who were trying to get people off the streets ahead of the 7pm curfew. In the video shared by NTV Kenya on its handle, Wainaina can be heard saying: “its not 6PM yet”. The police officer tells him, “I have forgiven you, you’re like my brother”, says something about throwing stones and claims that they can’t wait for 6PM. But even if it was after curfew, the government of Kenya has declared media( licensed broadcasters and media houses) part of the essential personnel that are allowed to be out and about at night.
State governor, Wike sacks journalists including Vincent Ake for story on COVID-19
Restricted movement: Journalists need ID cards to move around during lockdown

Kudzanai Musengi. Practicing as a journalist without vald accreditation while photographin lockdwon effects.  But Zim Media Commission in January authorized jorunalists to continue working using their 2029 accreditaiton until further notice. New fees and accresitiatoin notice only issue on  MArch 27
Tatenda Julius,  Arrested for practising as a journo without valid accredition and detained overnight. Paid a fine next day and was released/

Disaster Management Regulations criminalizes the publishing of any statement, through any memida, including social media, with the intention to deceive any other person about COVID-19, the infection status of any person or any measure taken by the government to address COVID-19, liable on conviction to a fine or 6 months in jail or both

Policeman deliberately fires at Azarrah Karrim with rubber bullets. Journaiist was filming Day of the lockdown when police forcibly dispered shoppers queing at a supremarket for food. Police dispersed the shoppers and chased after them. One policeman saw here filming and shot at her, despite her shouting she was a journalist and then chased her into a restaurant, where two of his colleagues intervened. She has laid a charge and complained to IPID
Link: https://www.news24.com/SouthAfrica/News/police-clash-with-joburg-residents-news24-reporter-caught-in-crossfire-20200327 AQ spoke to journo herself who sent a recording of what happened to her that is a lot jore serious than what appeas in this article

Description: Prime TV suspended and taken off Top Star platform after owner tells government to pay for Coronvirus adverts
This heavy-handed policeman confiscates #photographer Tracey Adam's cell as she takes footage of an assault in Capricorn Park.
Journalist infected, newsroom SABC goes into quarantine
Cellphone companies agree to hand over location date to government for COVID tracking

A local pastor, Augustine Yiga, was arrested in connection to comments he made to the media about COVID19. The ministry of health asked police to arrest a pastor, Augustine Yiga, who in tv broadcast called the Coronavirus pandemic a hoax. Today (March 30) morning he was remanded to prison after being charged with spreading harmful propaganda. Prosecution claims that he knew or had reason to believe that his comments were likely to spread COVID19, according to the Daily Monitor. The ministry also wants the Uganda Communications Commission to take action against the pastor and his radio station, ABS.

The justice system accused the two newspapers of having published a statement from the group of lawyers for an Ivorian opposition MP, Alain Lobognon, arrested and imprisoned at the end of December for complicity in a supposed attempt at “insurrection”. The lawyers were concerned about the conditions of incarceration in the context of the coronavirus pandemic and requested the release of their client.
The app, developed by the Ministry of the Interior and Safety, allows those who have been ordered not to leave home to stay in contact with case workers and report on their progress

The South Korean government is publishing the movements of people before they were diagnosed with the virus — retracing their steps using tools such as GPS phone tracking, credit card records, surveillance video and old-fashioned personal interviews with patients. The idea is to let the public know, via a central website and regional text messages, if they may have crossed paths with carriers, whose names are not made public.
South Korea is using credit-card transactions to track patients’ travel routes, and it started using a GPS-based app to monitor people under self-quarantine.
Government confirmed patient movement path
Singapore’s government hosts a website that includes the age, gender and occupation of all its coronavirus patients — and where they traveled recently
Singapore’s health authorities have tapped ride-sharing data and surveillance cameras to do the same
Mobile phone tracking

App meant to track suspected coronavirus cases lets the government track citizen movements, build social profiles by accessing their phone contacts without permission, store information in perpetuity, and share the information with any other agency for any other purpose. It is also unclear which government agency is overseeing the database and data collection.

"Chief Minister Arvind Kejriwal on Wednesday announced that the mobile phones of all those who have been asked to home quarantine themselves will be tracked by the Delhi Police to keep a check on their movement."

Report on the findings of "ProPublica’s research [that] tracked how the government-linked influence accounts that had targeted political dissidents and the Hong Kong protests turned their focus to the coronavirus outbreak. During the height of the epidemic in China, many of [these accounts] became cheerleaders for the government, calling on citizens to unite in support of efforts to fight the epidemic and urging them to 'dispel online rumors.' With the epidemic spreading across the world, these accounts have sought to promote the Chinese government’s image abroad and shore up its support at home."

YY, a live-streaming platform in China, began to censor keywords related to the coronavirus outbreak on December 31, 2019, a day after doctors (including the late Dr. Li Wenliang) tried to warn the public about the then unknown virus.

The Cyberspace Administration of China (CAC), the top-level Internet governance agency in China, issued a public statement stressing that it would punish “websites, platforms, and accounts” for publishing “harmful” content and “spreading fear” related to COVID-19. The CAC singled out Sina Weibo, Tencent, and ByteDance in the statement, saying that it would carry out “thematic inspection” of their platforms.
By this date, the CHRD has documented 897 netizens punished for “spreading rumours.”

4 people in Taiwan were charged with violating the Social Order Maintenance Act and the Criminal Codes by spreading rumors about the epidemic online. The contents they posted were conspiracy theories about the Taiwanese government stockpiling surgical masks for the rich. So far, no journalists affected.

New legislation. "According to Taiwan’s Special Act on COVID-19 Prevention, Relief, and Restoration passed on Feb. 25, individuals who spread rumors or disinformation about COVID-19 that risk harming the public interest can face a maximum prison term of three years and a possible fine of NT$3 million (US$99,000)."
Aajtak journalist Naveen Kumar was beaten up by police on his way to work
Jansandesh Times report Vijay Kumar Singh was beaten up by police on his way to work
Link: Copy of police complaint with Kunal

Description: Police in Hyderabad also beat and insulted Mendu Srinivas, political bureau chief of Telugu-language daily Andhra Jyothy,  for alleged lockdown violations while he was returning from work
Police in Hyderabad hit Mohammed Hussain, a reporter for the English news website Siasat, for alleged lockdown violations while he was returning from work

Thai sports reporter Noppadol Sritaweekard is first reported member of Thai media to contract Covid-19. He was infected while covering a boxing event that has emerged as a major cluster of infections in the country.
ETV deputy news editor Uttkarsh Chaturvedi was beaten up by the police while reporting on the locknown in Thane district in Maharashtra, despite showing his press card

KK Saxena became the first Indian journalist to be infected by COVID19. He got the virus from his daughter who returned from the UK.  He had attended two press conferences just before he was tested positive. A case of "negligent act likely to spread infection of disease dangerous to life" have been filed against him by Bhopal police because he attended two important press conferences even though his daughter was quarantined
Varanasi district magistrate Kaushal Raj Sharma sent a legal notice to Jansandesh Time over an article claimed some villager had nothing to eat due to lockdown.

Kantipur Media Group shuts print publication; Three dailies, four weeklies shut down in Dailekh Dullu, Province no. 6; Publication of local newspapers closed in Dang, Province no. 5; Newspapers shut publication in the Saptari District, Province 2.

The "last-minute amendment to President Rodrigo Duterte's special powers bill to contain the novel coronavirus was an expansion of the section on penalties, which now specifically punishes the spreading of fake and alarming information by up 2 months in prison and up to P1 million in fines. [...] Former Supreme Court spokesperson Ted Te said the subparagraph on the punishment of fake news: "'since there is no law that criminizalizes or defines fake news as a crime, and the special powers law does not also define what fake news is, it cannot be criminalized. That would be void.'"

"Only resource speakers and state media workers are now allowed to access the Malacañang Press Briefing Room, where public officials give announcements and give updates on the government’s response to the new coronavirus."

Government uses false news law to order STR to correct false statements it made on government adhering to WHO guidelines . This raises question of whether it is acceptable for a governemnt to make decisions about what information can be taken down, when that information is in fact blatantly false as in this case.

Government files three criminal charges against journalist Wan Noor Hayati Wan Alias under penal code Section 505(b) for causing “fear or alarm to the public” or “commit an offense against the State or public tranquility” over three coronavirus related tweets. Trial ongoing; she faces a possible six years in prison

"Prime Minister Prayut Chan-o-cha said today that the worst thing about the ongoing novel coronavirus situation in Thailand is panic caused by fake news, as he warned those with ill-intent that they will be dealt with decisively and in accordance with the law."

Just a tiny handful of print publications will continue through the lockdown, with only daily newspapers specifically identified as being able to continue. Duncan Greive spoke to publishers of magazines and community newspapers about the impact on them and their communities.

"Chief Minister Arvind Kejriwal on Wednesday announced that the mobile phones of all those who have been asked to home quarantine themselves will be tracked by the Delhi Police to keep a check on their movement."

The German conglomerate, which owns magazines including The Listener, New Zealand Woman's Weekly, Woman's Day, North & South, Metro, Fashion Quarterly and Next announced on Thursday it would shut down its New Zealand operations and make all staff redundant, blaming the economic impact of the coronavirus pandemic for its decision.

"The Express Group has informed its employees that the organisation will be going for a temporary salary cut" as a result of a hit to advertising revenue and risks related to the distribution of print media.

"Local authorities have already fined hundreds of people for posting what they described as “fake news” about the virus [...] based on existing legal provisions." But there is new decree, drafted in February, that supersedes one from 2013. "A fine of 10-20 million dong ($426-$853), equivalent to around three to six months’ basic salary in Vietnam, will be imposed on people who use social media to share false, untruthful, distorted, or slanderous information, according to the decree."

The Information Ministry announced that it has formed a unit to monitor social media and various television outlets for “rumors” about COVID-19 cases. So far, no reports of journalists, but the authorities have apparently arrested at least a dozen people, including a doctor, opposition activists, and students, for their comments about coronavirus, most of them under the draconian Digital Security Act.

The interim government of Bolivia announced this Wednesday that it would be performing cyberpatrols of social media content in order to identify who is responsible for disinformation campaigns related to the coronavirus (COVID-19).

Brazilian Health Ministry announced on 3/27 it planned to track cellular/location data of citizens for "public health policy," via the Ministry of Science, Innovation, Tech and Communications (Ministério da Ciência, Inovação, Tecnologia e Comunicação). On 4/2, five of Brazil's largest telecoms providers - Algar, Claro, Oi, Tim and Vivo - agreed to cooperate with this initiative, granting access to more than 222 million phone numbers.

Ecuador's Ministry of Government indicated that the government will track the cellular data of certain individuals in an attempt to contain the spread of the virus. The data will also be used to determine to what extent people are staying at home.

"The country had one confirmed case when the app was released. In an analysis of the app, Fundación Karisma found many concerns. The app is a version of one made for the Rio de Janeiro Olympics, adapted in 2017 to strengthen surveillance of public health risks, and has bugs that make it unusable. None of the functions, not even the safety information, are accessible without filling out the registration form, which requires full name, sex, data of birth, ethnicity, and email, with no clarity in the terms and conditions about how the information will be protected and used"

Socorro has been target of coordinated state trolling. Includes a Vice-Minister sending Socorro a tweet (https://twitter.com/planwac/status/1236401422477950979?s=20) from his official account. She sent Ana Cristina all of the screen shots of the tweets. She has been a strong critic of the government, and has had her Twitter account hacked in the past.

Journalist Gregoria Diaz received insults and threats through Twitter, Instagram and WhatsApp after reporting via Twitter of a possible case of Coronavirus of a citizen from China, in the city of Maracay, on February 21. The mayor herself retweeted the campaign on social media to discredit Díaz. She has also been harassed by local officials since posting the tweet.

Jesús Enrique Torres and Jesus Manuel Castillo were detained by police on March 13.Castillo and Torres appeared before a judge in Los Teques on March 15, when they were charged with “crimes against the state” and released, according to Carlos Torres, the father of Jesús Torres, who spoke to Espacio Público but did not cite any specific laws the journalists were alleged to have broken. The journalists are required to register their whereabouts with authorities once a week as their legal case proceeds, Murolo said.

A Chilean citizen was arrested after telling Argentine TV repoter Marco Bustamante to "stop lying," coughing in his face and falsely saying he had coronavirus during a segment on the pandemic at the Retiro bus terminal
"The people will soon see that they were tricked by these governors and by the large part of the media when it comes to coronavirus," Bolsonaro said in a television interview on 3/22.
Melquiades Avila was threatened multiple times and is now in hiding.

Police detained Cosmos Televisión journalist Martín Gonzáles Salazar for about half an hour around 8:30 pm, when he was returning home from work, for breaking curfew. Even though he showed them documentation, including his press pass, the officers said the documents weren't valid "in a state of emergency." He was eventually released, Peruvian journalists' association made a statement on his behalf, seems like a case of police officers not being informed about journalists' permission to be out during curfew
FAES and Cicpc agents detained and questioned journalist Kerlin Mosquera (Diario 2001) as he was conducting reporting on the reactions of citizens to the quarantine measures.

Website coronavirus.info blocked in Venezuela by the State-owned internet provider. It was created by the opposition-controlled National Assembly to convey information to Venezuelans on the pandemic, including recommendations and information.

Agents of the municipal police detained journalist Ariadna Limon and photographer Tairy Gamboa (both of Cronica Uno) while they were in Catia covering the quarantine situation. They had their IDs taken from them and were forced to delete material.

Mariana de Barros, a reporter for @VivoPlayNet, wasn't allowed to enter Caracas even after presenting her press card and a video of the order by Minister Padrinio López to allow members of the press to perform their work.

Police detained Hoy photojournalist José Adames Arias for violating curfew while he was on his way home; Decree 135-20 allows accredited members of the press to be out during curfew. Adames was released without charges.

Police briefly detained TV presenter Milagros Leiva after she became confrontational and allegedly refused to show documents after being stopped by police for driving during curfew; Leiva argues that she had permission to be out because she's a journalist but it's not clear she was working at the time
Journalist Darvison Rojas is detained, as are his parents. Darvison was released after 13 days (April 2).
A team of Red Bolivisión workers was illegaly retained and verbally attacked by shopkeepers in the San Antonio market

Journalist Sharina Henriquez was detained for two hours by the police as she returned home after reporting how tourists were facing Covid19 stranded on the island.  She was also fined 1000 guilders ($500).
José Benítez (+cameraman) Police detained them for allegedly violating curfew, though press workers are excluded. Released later that same day.
Police hit Paola Cobo + other journalists documenting the moment when police are detaining invidividuals for failing to comply with curfew imposed due to Coronavirus
Government restricts for a third time the press's right to ask questions during a press conference on March 23. First case on March 17 and the second on March 22.

Two soldiers and a security guard at the CIFCO convention center stopped a TV journalist from taking photos outside the center, which is being converted to an emergency hospital for COVID-19 patients. Unnamed journalist and unidentified outlet

Police in Puerto Plata detained Ramón Emilio Fernández and accused him of causing "confusion among the population" by spreading false information. Fernández had shared on social media information about the government-imposed curfew that had the incorrect hours - seems like it was an honest mistake and not an attempt to trick people but he was still arrested. It's not entirely clear whether he falls under our definition of journalist - news sources have also described him as a lawyer, local media groups said he's not a journalist so it's a little messy. He's charged with sharing false information (will try to get exact charges) under Artículo 27 de la ley 61-32 sobre Libre Expresión y Difusión del Pensamiento.

"Members of the media were physically and verbally assaulted by security guards at the San Fernando General Hospital yesterday. TV6 video journalist Cindy Raghubar-Teekasingh and Che Teekasingh were standing at the car park recording footage of a COVID-19 screening area [...] when they were accosted by the guards. There have been similar assaults on media personnel by security guards at the hospital over the years."

Beatriz Rodriguez. Police take from her home to the prosecutor's office to interrogate her on a report of a case that tested positive for Coronavirus published in the La Verdad daily, where she is the Editor. She is interrogated again on the 25. She is being pressured to reveal sources.

Rosalí Hernández, Caraota Digital. Special forces agents FAES detain her for 40 min and force her to delete the videos she had recorded showing the cleaning/ sterilization of streets ordered by the government to fight the pandemic.
Yarnaldo Tovar, 360 Grados Internacional. Detained by the national police outisde a hospital (Hospital Pereférico de Coche), Caracas, covering coronavirus. Released several hours later.

Interim president Jeanine Áñez signed Supreme Decree 4200, amplifying a number of quarantine measures. One of the articles (13.II) stipulates that "people who incite others to not follow the Supreme Decree or who disinform the public or generate uncertainty will be subject to criminal charges by the Commission of crimes against public health.
Police interrogated Cubanet reporter Camila Acosta about her Facebook posts on COVID19.
Miguel Eduardo Taveras detained and handcuffed by police for alleged breach of curfew, though press is exempted.
Ralph Zapata of OjoPublico detained inside his home by 10 policemen, taken to the police station.
Police interrogated Fernández Cuenca in the police station in Aguilera (La Habana) and threatened to impose strict penalties in response to his work.
Police detained Yusleidi Romero (Panorama Pinañero - ICLEP), interrogated and threatened her with prison and issued her a 'warning' related to her reporting on COVID19.

govt, Inter-American Dev Bank, a startup (Emerge), and the Penta Network  "While countries like Israel and China implement coronavirus emergency measures that digitally track civilian location data and health records, an entrepreneur in Honduras developed a blockchain-powered equivalent with an acute focus on privacy. The bootstrapped startup Emerge is working with the Inter-American Development Bank, the tech company Penta Network and the Emergency Response Unit of the Honduran government to launch an app this week called Civitas. This software program will associate people’s government ID numbers with unique blockchain records they can use for telemedicine and permits to leave the house on specific errands."

Radio journalist Lucker Désir is arrested after saying that there were no coronavirus in Haiti and calling on people not to wear masks. He was provided a 'warning' and quickly released after a mob outside the station demanded his release.

Military officials detained Faustino Reyes Díaz, a journalist for TV station Telemicro and newspaper Listín Diario, interrogated and held him for two hours and deleted materials that he had recorded while reporting on alleged smuggling operations taking place after curfew

News outlet Agencia Nova claims the governor of Corrientes threatened criminal charges against its reporter, Jacinto Aguirre, and officials "censored" him (apparently by ordering him to obey quarantine) after he reported on allegedly inadequate measures taken to quarantine a woman who returned from Argentina to Brazil. There's not a whole lot of detail in this one, it seems like he tried to interview her and her family members and then officials got mad about it and told him he needed to quarantine and the news outlet is arguing that is censorship
Journalist Osniel Carmona detained, interrogated and threatened with being 'dissapeared' by state security for distrubuting a community newspaper Amanecer Habanero (ICLEP) covering COVID-19.
Two journalists detained after writing corona-related story. The story was deleted from the website, haberimizvar.net, after the journalists were released.
FR to track CV quarantine
Telekom Austria AG, the country’s biggest telecom network operator, is providing “anonymized data” to relevant authorities, according to a statement late Tuesday.

Vodafone Group Plc said in a statement it’s providing Italian officials with anonymized customer data to track and analyze population movements in the hard-hit Lombardy region, where people are in lockdown.

The Polish government has developed the free Home Quarantine app, [...] which allows the police to check that individuals do not break quarantine; those who do may be fined up to PLN 5,000. [...] Once users activate the app by entering a phone number and a code sent via SMS, they send a reference photo. Every so often the app sends an unscheduled request for a new photo to be sent within 20 minutes. The system checks both the person (using facial recognition) and the location, essentially replicating what would otherwise be a visit from a police officer. Non-quarantined people cannot sign up, as the app is connected to a database of telephone numbers belonging to those ordered into quarantine. [...] The government intends to add more functionality to the app over time.
"The police in Madrid are now deploying their own spies in the skies, filming streets and parks, using its onboard speaker to order people home."

"The cameras are controlled from a purpose-built coronavirus control centre. Images and personal details of those under quarantine are put on a database so they can be recognised by the cameras. The centre can also be used to monitor social media for ‘fake news’ on the coronavirus, according to officials."

"Serbia picked up the baton, though the scale of wiretapping and surveillance remain undisclosed as the only person to talk about it is President Aleksandar Vucic. 'We follow telephone numbers, Italian above all,' Vucic told reporters on March 19. 'We are not tapping,' he said, 'we are following are they moving, people with Italian numbers in roaming – and yes, they are'."

The UK govenment is preparing to release an app in order to alert "people if they come too close to someone who has tested positive for COVID-19." This "UK version follows the example set by TraceTogether, a Bluetooth-powered app used in Singapore, which has been downloaded more than 800,000 times, and helped the city-state substantially suppress its coronavirus outbreak."
TK- program researching

Looks at the panic and riots that took place in Novi Sanzhary, Ukraine, largely due to a disinformation campaign related to the virus. "Looking back, residents [of the city], including doctors, said the anger and panic were stoked by the government’s decision to withhold information from them, misinformation that spread across social media, and sensational coverage by the news media.

"Pro-Kremlin media have been spreading disinformation about coronavirus with the aim of 'aggravating' the public health crisis in the west, the European Union’s diplomatic service has concluded in a leaked report." This article reviews several of the 80 examples of disinformation from Russian sources the EU Monitor recored between January 16 to March 16.

"President Ilham Aliyev, in his address to the nation for the Nowruz spring holiday, enumerated the country’s various economic, political, and diplomatic accomplishments - the usual. But in part of the speech he also took a strikingly darker tone, describing Azerbaijan’s response to the coronavirus and warning that while the government was acting decisively, there were “provocations” coming from a 'fifth column.'" The president's statement made open threats against this "fifth column."

New law will permanently amend two articles of the criminal code that will further limit freedom of expression and penalize people for breaching quarantine orders. It will also suspend all elections and referendums. Under one measure, anyone who disseminates information that could hinder the government’s response to the epidemic could face up to five years in prison. The legislation gives broad latitude to the public prosecutor to determine what counts as distorted or false information.Lawyer Daniel Karsai echoes same point as Gulnoza--this marks birth of dictatorship

"The Armenian authorities have aggressively gone after media and social media users for spreading non-official information about coronavirus, prompting journalism organizations in the country to protest that the government is overreacting." One of the provisions of the March 16 State of Emergency is a "ban on publishing or sharing any information on the outbreak that didn’t come from the Armenian government or other countries’ official sources. Since then, the police have taken an expansive view of what they consider a violation of that rule." "The newspaper and website Hraparak was forced to delete a story about prisoners complaining that the outbreak meant that they couldn’t receive packages from outside."The news website Aravot was forced to edit a story that cited Russian analyst Valeriy Solovey, speaking on the radio show Ekho Moskvy, claiming that Russia was hiding the true scope of the coronavirus outbreak in that country." "Marine Kharatyan, said police visited her and demanded she delete a Facebook post she wrote about one large factory in Armenia that was requiring employees to come to work even if they were running a fever."

İdris Özyol (chief editor) and Ebru Özaydın (editor) from the local online newspaper Haberimiz Var were detained by the police from their houses and questioned about their reporting on Coronavirus. They were released after questioning. The story in question was deleted.

Freelance journalist Aydın Atay was called by the police to be questioned about his tweet on Coronavirus (Diyarbakır Courthouse is closed due to Coronavirus). He was released after offering testimony to the police.
16 field reporters and camera personnel of the Demirören Media Group were forced to work inside a container in front of their offices as a precaution.

İsmet Çiğit (chief editor), Ahmet Seminer (responsible news editor) and Güngör Arslan (İnternet editor) from the local newspaper SES Kocaeli were detained by the police from their houses at night and questioned about their reporting on Coronavirus. They were released after questioning. The story in question was deleted.

Tugay Can, reporter for the local newspaper İz Gazete, was called by the police to be questioned about his reporting on Coronavirus (two medical workers in two different districts of Izmir tested positive). He was released after offering testimony to the police.
Interior minister said almost 2,000 social media accounts had been identified making provocative posts about the outbreak, resulting in the detention of 410 people "attempting to stir unrest."
Government media watchdog RTÜK fined three TV channels due to their reporting on Coronavirus: Halk TV, TELE1 and Habertürk.
Nurcan Baysal, writer and columnist for critical online outlet Ahval, was called to testify about her tweets on the Coronavirus pandemic. She was let go after ater questioned.
Oktay Candemir, local journalist from the eastern province of Van, was called to testify about his reporting on Coronavirus.

"A journalist group of NewsOne TV channel was attacked during a journalistic investigation [on the illegal mask trade] in the city of Krasiyliv of Khmelnytsky region." The channel's statement on the attack is linked in the article.
ministry official attacks reporter covering #coronavirus event (not clear whether related to reporting)

A journalist of Serbian Nova.rs portal Ana Lalić was arrested on Wednesday evening on charges of causing panic and unrest for reporting on the difficult situation in the Clinical Centre of Vojvodina (KCV). She was ordered a 48-hour arrest pending interrogation by a prosecutor, but was released on Thursday morning. Nevertheless, her laptop and mobile phone have been kept by the police. KCV denies the reports on the conditions of its workers.

Government severly restricts flow of information on coronavirus, 
J-association warns of censorship
NHS staff 'gagged' over coronavirus shortages

On 3/30, "Russian lawmakers [approved] fines of up to $25,000 and prison terms of up to five years for anyone who spreads what is deemed to be false information. Media outlets will be fined up to $127,000 if they disseminate disinformation about the outbreak."
TV crew of public broadcaster attacked
hospital put pressure on investigative journalist in coronavirus reporting

citizen journalist detained while documenting a demonstration
 under coronavirus state of emergency

journalists shortly detained and charged for allegedly not following
sanitary guidelines
J-association warns against using criminal code provisions against journalists #coronavirus
Journalists covering coronavirus attacked by street vendors in Turin
PM verbally attacks TV crew for coronavirus reporting

"A short-lived order for media in Moldova to refrain from printing or broadcasting ‘opinion’ and to convey only the position of authorities during a state of emergency imposed to aid the fight against the COVID-19 pandemic has set alarm bells ringing in the former Soviet republic." The [March 24] decree was issued states that "journalists will unilaterally renounce formulating their own opinion or other arbitrary opinions in reflecting on topics concerning the COVID-19 pandemic."
newspaper reporter and photographer covering #coronavirus threatened by local

Association of Journalists of Kosovo has been informed that the team of ‘Blic newspaper”, journalists Nebih Maxhuni, Diamant Bajra, and the cameraman Arsim Rexhepi, have been physically attacked today in northern Mitrovica while reporting on the Corona virus situation.

As ‘Blic newspaper’ reports, the team approached a location where flour was being sold, in order to interview citizens, and they were attacked by two citizens, being punched and kicked.

The journalist Maxhuni is currently at the Mitrovica City hospital where he is receiving medical treatment.

journalist verbally assaulted by municipal leader over 
coronavirus criticism

Investigative journalist attacked in probably government
 orchestrated smear campaign
Authorities Suspect some News Outlets of Spreading "fakes"
The Police warned Zest Krasnodara not to spread "fakes"
A court date set in the case of Svetlana Prokopyeva

"There has been false news circulating about the Iranian government blocking an important coronavirus resource: the live updated map of infections and deaths by @JohnsHopkins. The website is blocked in Iran, but not because of Iran, but because of sanctions."
Iran's parliament announced any one who spreads False News about Coronavirus will be sentenced to 3 years in prison. (They see any coverage of the virus as False News anyway!!)
Arrested at least 24 people who were informing the public on social media by sharing news about coronavirus. Citizen jouranlists? Imprisoned? Fake News?

Radio journalist Lucker Désir is arrested after saying that there were no coronavirus in Haiti and calling on people not to wear masks. He was provided a 'warning' and quickly released after a mob outside the station demanded his release.
A group of Kurdish journalists charged (?) with disinformation (can we say fake news or no?)

"An international press watchdog says Iraqi officials have suspended Reuters news agency's license for three months after the British wire service reported that confirmed COVID-19 cases in the country exceeded official statistics. According to the New York-based Committee to Protect Journalists, Baghdad's Communications and Media Commission on Thursday barred the outlet and fined it 25 million Iraqi dinars ($21,000) the same day the report published."
Journalist Fardin Mostafaei / arrested/ interrogated on charges of spreading misinformation/ false news relating to coronavirus under the Iran Penal code.
Mostafa Faghihi/ Journalist / charged under Iran penal code for spreading lies relating to coronavirus

Tehran Prosecutor General Ali Alghasi-Mehr had issued an order saying, “in order to manage public opinion and the media, the judiciary will identify, document, and summon those who spread false news through various news websites, social media channels, such as Instagram, and other news sources in the shortest time possible.”
150 citizen journlaists and social media users who were informing the public were arrested
Gov't revokes press credentials for Ruth Michaelson and threatens NYTimes reporter Declan Walsh
an emergency “defense law” gave wide latitude to Prime Minister Omar Razzaz, who said his government would “deal firmly” with anyone who spreads “rumors, fabrications and false news that sows panic.”

One of the new decisions (number 4 of 7): "4. Stopping the printing of newspapers, magazines and publications of all kinds and preventing their circulation, and preventing the sale and circulation of newspapers, magazines and publications issued outside the Sultanate."

Abdollah Seyed Ahmadi Zavieh,  editor of the state-run Fars news agency, passed away after contracting COVID 19 . Noteworthy given how bad the outbreak has been there plus Iranian government's contradictory positions on dangers faced by media workers, including the fact they do not consider them essential workers and thus do not offer them extra health protections

"The Ministry of Culture, Youth and Sports has called on all newspaper publishers to suspend any publication and distribution as of Sunday until further notice. This call falls within the framework of the state of health emergency in force in the Kingdom of Morocco and the implementation of the measures taken to fight the propagation of the coronavirus Covid-19, said a press release from the ministry."
Reza Entesari, imprisoned 2.19.2018, was released in response to government efforts to limit spread of virus

Hemin Mamand was arrested by the police of the Kurdistan Regional Government at his house in Erbil. He remains in detention without charges. The arrest [...] is linked to a complaint submitted by the Governor of Erbil to the Public Prosecution, regarding a social media post where Hemin Mamand criticised the economic measures taken by the Kurdish government in response to the COVID-19 outbreak as violating the economic rights of the Kurdish people. The investigative judge ordered his detention until 2 April 2020. His request for release on bail was rejected and his detention may be extended."
Coronavirus Combat Taskforce banned all print media. The ban will be in place as long as coronavirus-related restrictions are in effect.

At least 19 Iranian journalists who work for the state's main broadcasting the Islamic Republic of Iran Broadcasting (IRIB) are infected with the virus. Most were infected while covering February election. Iranian journalists are not considered essential workers so they are not provided PPE that other front line workers have access to.

NSO Group. The software takes two weeks of mobile-phone tracking information from the infected person - the incubation time of the virus -- then matches with location data collected by national mobile phone companies that pinpoints citizens who were in the patient’s vicinity for more than 15 minutes and are vulnerable to contagion
Iran's official COVID-19 detection app raises a number of privacy and security concerns. It has been removed from Google Play store.

Security agents in the western Iranian city of Kermanshah arrested and detained Kurdish Iranian journalist Gholamreza Noori Ala for several hours and then released him, after he shared a story he wrote on the telegram channel of the Naghdehall newspaper, his employer, alleging that Kermanshah’s governor tested positive with the COVID-19 virus. CPJ could not determine whether charges have been formally filed against him.
The White House prohibited audio and video coverage of a critical briefing on coronavirus

The Cleveland (Ohio) Plain Dealer announced it would cut 22 newsroom employees. “The reason is strictly financial,” editor Tim Warsinskey wrote. In the Cleveland Scene, Sam Allard reported, “This round of layoffs follows cuts last year in which the jobs of layout editors and designers were outsourced and 12 newsroom positions were eliminated shortly thereafter. The current layoffs will further diminish the PD’s unionized workforce and calls into question what a ‘daily’ print newspaper in Cleveland will even consist of.”
Access. White House told federal health officials to classify coronavirus deliberations.
The Stranger in Seattle temporarily suspended print and laid off 18 staffers.
Harassed. Reporter yelled at while asking questions about coronavirus.
Reporters cut off repeatedly during WH briefing; President calls PBS correspondent's question "nasty"
Access. Journalist turned away from briefing following temperature screening. Not sure we should call this a press freedom violation, but good to have on here
Surgeon general tells reporters "no more finger pointing." Again, don't think we want to call this a press freedom violation, but good to track

Portland Mercury (Oregon) announced it was temporarily cutting print and had temporarily laid off 10 staffers “spanning editorial, calendar, sales, and circulation, while simultaneously making deep cuts to the remaining managers’ salaries.”

"The day after he became the focus of sharp criticism for urging Fox News viewers to go out to their local restaurants and pubs in direct contradiction of CDC guidelines, Rep. Devin Nunes (R-CA) claimed 'media freaks' were distorting his remarks."
"The Trump administration is alleging that a foreign disinformation campaign is underway aimed at spreading fear in the country amid the coronavirus pandemic, three U.S. officials said Monday."
DigBoston suspended print publication.
Change to WH briefing seating
The FBI Has Limited Public Records Requests During The Coronavirus Pandemic
Athena Security "artificially intelligent thermal cameras" that it claims will be able to detect fevers in people, and in turn send an alert that they may be carrying the coronavirus

Carbyn (Israeli company)Once a caller uses their Android or iPhone to call 911 (85% of emergency calls now come from mobile devices), they receive a text message that asks for permission to get their precise location and access video from their smartphone camera.
Reno (Nevada) News & Review suspended print and laid off staff.
Sacramento (California) News & Review and Chico (California) News & Review suspended print and laid off staff.
Salaries were cut at the Phoenix New Times
Salaries were cut at Denver’s Westword
Salaries were cut at the Dallas Observer and Houston Press
Salaries were cut at the Miami New Times.

Discusses the results of a survey that asked Americans to rate the performance of the media's coverage of coronavirus. General findings of the survey: a) "Americans give the news media fairly high marks for their coverage of COVID-19, though most think their reporting has at least somewhat exaggerated the risks"; b) "About half the public (48%) say they’ve been exposed to at least some made-up news and information related to the virus"; and, c) "substantial portions [of survey respondents] express belief in claims that are in fact false" (e.g., 29% think it was created in a lab).
The main CBC network will replace local nightly newscasts in all areas except stations in the north.
Tampa Bay Times, which Poynter owns, laid off 11 journalists, noting the cuts were expected since February.
Shepherd Express in Milwaukee suspended its print edition.
The Pulse in Chattanooga, Tennessee, suspended publication.
Texas’ San Antonio Current laid off 10 employees. “The cuts came from virtually every department, including sales, production, editorial and events.”
CityBeat in Cincinnati had furloughs and pay cuts.
MetroTimes in Detroit laid off eight staffers.
Cleveland Scene in Ohio laid off five staffers.
Orlando Weekly laid off 13 people.
Oklahoma Gazette in Oklahoma City paused print publication
Rachel Kurzius reported for DCist that Washingtonian magazine laid off fellows and had 10% pay cuts.
Isthmus, a weekly in Madison, Wisconsin, announced it had to “go dark for an undetermined amount of time."
Trump accuses press of 'siding with China' amid pandemic
Chiling statement. U.S. Senator Richard Burr: "In a tabloid-style hit piece today, NPR knowingly and irresponsibly misrepresented a speech I gave last month about the coronavirus threat."
Austin Chronicle in Texas went from weekly to an every-other-week print schedule.
Mountain Xpress in Asheville, North Carolina, laid off seven and had pay cuts.
Trent Stephens reported for The Durango (Colorado) Herald that it had laid off five people from its news and advertising departments.

Trib Total Media combined two print editions and laid off staff, according to Joyce Gannon in the Pittsburgh Post-Gazette. “In a statement to readers published in Monday’s edition, Jennifer Bertetto, president and chief executive, said the combination of its editions ‘is a temporary adjustment in reaction to extraordinary circumstances.’”
San Diego closed and laid off its entire staff, Ken Stone reported for Times of San Diego.
The Times-Picayune/nola.com/The Advocate in New Orleans announced a temporary furlough of 10% of its workforce
D Magazine in Dallas reported layoffs and salary cuts. “We lost 15 people, including editors, designers, sales people, and administrative personnel.”

The Warwick Beacon in Rhode Island cut one publication day to become a weekly and had eight layoffs, including the publisher, Paul Edward Parker reported in The Providence Journal. “I just totally took myself off the payroll,” said publisher John Howell.

Maxwell Tani reported for The Daily Beast that BuzzFeed was cutting employee pay. “In an internal memo on Wednesday, the company announced a graduated salary reduction for the majority of employees for the months of April and May, adding that company brass would meet with the news union to ratify the cuts.”

The 13-year-old Waterbury Record reported it printed its last edition. “Clearly, this decision is precipitated by the coronavirus crisis, but it’s also about economics,” said publisher Greg Popa in the Record. “The Record has never been profitable, but we were in this for the long haul.”

Disinformation. In a statement, Judd Deere, a White House spokesman, said that “any suggestion that President Trump did not take the threat of Covid-19 seriously or that the United States was not prepared is false.” Not directed specifically at any journalist or news organization, it seems, but nonetheless thought worth flagging given the magnitude of the problem of disinformation/misinformation in the US around things like testing and also use of 'false' label
Reporter for the Miami Herald and Tampa Bay Times not allowed into governor's press briefing on covid-19

Edmonds reported that Gannett told its newsrooms around the country that it was going to begin furloughs and other cost-cutting measures, including 25% pay reductions for executives. “Our plan is to minimize long-term damage to the business by implementing a combination of furloughs and pay reductions,” operating CEO Paul Bascobert said in a memo to staff.

The Times Leader in Wilkes-Barre announced it’s cutting print on Saturday, Monday and Tuesday. A note to readers said “As we move forward, we need to make some changes in how we do business to remain a viable resource for you.”

The Henrico Citizen in Henrico County announced it was stopping its twice-monthly print edition for April “and possibly beyond.” “Halting our print edition does not mean that we are slowing our local news coverage efforts,” wrote Tom Lappas, founder and publisher.

Adams Publishing Group, which operates dailies and weeklies in 20 states, announced a cut in workforce hours, according to The (Mankato, Minnesota) Free Press. “They own more than 60 papers in Minnesota as well as papers in other states,” the Free Press reported.
The Street reported layoffs and pay cuts at Maven Media Brands, which operates Sports Illustrated.

Paul Heintz reported for Seven Days that VTDigger, a nonprofit digital news site in Vermont, announced its first three layoffs since launching 10 years ago. The cuts “include one part-time newsroom employee, as well as one full-time and one part-time member of the organization’s business staff.”

Tani reported for The Daily Beast that Vice cut some pay and stopped 401K matching and promotions. “Additionally, the company announced that anyone making more than $100,000 per year would receive a pay cut, and that some top executives would take a furlough and a 20-to-25% pay decrease while the company weathers the storm.”

"Anyone who does not adhere to this policy, or who speaks or disseminates information to the
media without explicit permission of the Office of Communications and Marketing, will be
subject to disciplinary action, including termination” - policy of NYU Langone

Lee Enterprises told its newsrooms around the country that it was instituting furloughs and cost-cutting measures, including a 20% pay cut for executives. “All other employees will be subject to either a pay reduction or furlough equivalent to two weeks of salary also in the third quarter,” Lee President and CEO Kevin Mowbray wrote in a memo to staff.
The Capital Times in Madison, Wisconsin, announced furloughs and pay cuts. Scott Gordon reported the news for Tone Madison.
East Oregonian reported its parent company laid off 47

The San Francisco Examiner and SF Weekly announced cuts in hours and pay to staff. “Due to the deep declines in advertising and because fewer people are in The City every day to pick up the print version of our publications, we have temporarily stopped producing SF Weekly and SF Evergreen in print,” wrote Deborah Peterson, editor-in-chief.
Inside Radio reported pay cuts and layoffs at Town Square Media Group and furloughs and pay cuts at iHeartMedia stations.
Inside Radio reported on layoffs, pay cuts and furloughs at Beasley Media stations.
22nd Century Media, which published community newspapers in the Chicago suburbs, went out of business, according to Chicago media beat reporter Robert Feder.

Inside Radio reported on layoffs, pay cuts and furloughs at radio stations owned by Entercom around the country. “Entercom is the fourth major radio company to make extensive cuts this week in the wake of the COVID-19-fueled economic shutdown.”
Newsrooms that are part of Alden Global Capital’s MediaNews Group learned of layoffs and furloughs. (Includes The Denver Post, the Boston Herald and several in California)

Staffers at The Outline reported they’d all been laid off. Joshua Benton wrote about it for Nieman Lab. “Not quite 3 1/2 years after its launch, The Outline — the design-forward, millennial-focused, consciously weird site that aspired to be ‘a next-generation version of The New Yorker’ — is shutting down.”
Bustle Digital Group laid off two dozen staffers and implemented pay cuts, according to Sara Jerde in AdWeek.
G/O Media, which includes sites such as Jezebel, Deadspin, The Root and The Onion, laid off 14 employees.
Temporary pay cuts at The Dallas Morning News.
The Hastings Star Gazette’s and the Bulletin of Woodbury and Cottage Grove will stop publishing next month.
TEGNA announced furloughs and pay cuts company wide. According to Poynter’s Al Tompkins, “TEGNA is the first of the big TV owners to announce such cuts.”

"Gov. Wanda Vázquez assumed even more sweeping powers, signing an amendment that makes it illegal for media outlets or social media accounts 'to transmit or allow the transmission' of 'false information with the intention of creating confusion, panic, or public hysteria, with regards to any proclamation or executive order declaring an emergency, disaster or curfew.' If the false information causes more than $10,000 in damage to public-sector finances or leads to injury or damage of physical property, it will be considered a fourth-degree criminal offense, the governor’s office said."
Group Nine laid of 7% of staff. Group Nine publications include The Dodo, Thrillist and NowThis.

Southern Nevada Health District - new app was created where people who are under surveillance report their daily symptoms. If an individual fails to log their info, a disease investigator is informed.
MIT/Harvard Private Kit: Safe Paths. An app that tracks where you have been and who you have crossed paths with—and then shares this personal data with other users in a privacy-preserving way
DOJ seeking new emergency powers: indefinite detention

"Ming Lin, an emergency room physician in Washington state, said he was told Friday he was out of a job because he’d given an interview to a newspaper about a Facebook post detailing what he believed to be inadequate protective equipment and testing. In Chicago, a nurse was fired after emailing colleagues that she wanted to wear a more protective mask while on duty. In New York, the NYU Langone Health system has warned employees they could be terminated if they talk to the media without authorization."
Facebook sharing disease migration maps to help combat the spread (with USG)

Liberty University files trespassing charges against ProPublic journalist Alec MacGillis and photographer Julia Rendleman for reporting story on how the university is partially open during the pandemic
Journalists not allowed to attend Covid-19 press conference.
Investigative Committee open three cases on "fakes".
Russian authorities open the first case against a journalist concerning coronavirus
Three local journalists were called by the police to testify about their Coronavirus related reporting: Gençağa Karafazlı, Doğan Can İlek and Hasan Fehmi Demir. They were not taken into custody.
At the request of Prosecutor General’s Office some publications removed news about places in the cemetery where victims of coronavirus are buried.
New editor-in-chief- removed from newspaper’s website an article critical of Shechin.
Editor-chief of Mediazona summoned to Roskomnadzor
Chechen leader accuses Novaya Gazeta being "anti-chechen"
One more criminal case is opened against Gadziyev
BBC: The Investigative Committe told branches to press on "fakes"

President Erdoğan:"However, using this incident and outbreak measures in general as an excuse, some media outlets have, in a sense, started a war against their own country with their news and columnists, as they always do.

"Instead of contributing to the struggle of our country in this critical period, they are all holding a grudge with fabricated and false news, which is indicative of a disease more dangerous than the virus.

"Our country will hopefully get rid of not only coronavirus, but also these media and politics viruses as well."
More than three thousand patiens were detected in Russia in one day.
Veteran organizations asked Putin to ostpone Victory Parade
More than 100 people alredy died from coronavius in Moscow
RIA Novosty published a fake news that Prime Minister Boris Johnson was treated with a ventlator
The numbers of people using Internet sources grew up for about 100 million in March
